I have received a copy of your letter NO.1840-S of October 25th, 1947, to the Chancery of the British Embassy, Bagdad There is no teachers' training college for women which has been opened recently in Bagdad but there are three which have been in existence for several years. Of these three, one is for men and women which is evidently not what you want. The other two are for women but only one is good. This is the Queen Alia Institute for women only. The courses here are satisfactory, especially in the English branch. There are four British women lecturers, and they have the pick of the teachers leaving the Higher Teachers 1 Training College. The course is divided into two parts (1) (a) Four year course (b) Qualifications for entry: Iraq Secondary Cert. (c) Graduated students are sent to teach in Intermediate and Secondary schools. (d) There are English, Lituary and Scientific sections. (e) Boarders and non-boarders are taken. (2) (a) Five year course divided into: (i) Secondary School training (3 years) (ii) Training School to produce Primary teachers (2 years) (b) Qualifications for Entry: Iraq Intermediate Cert. (c) Students on graduation teach in Primary schools afterwards. (d) Boarders and non-boarders are taken. I am not sure for what grade the Bahrain Government requires the training of their teachers but I should think that this Institute would be the most suitable for them. If you would like me to make any further enquiries, I should be happy to do so. Yours ever, Sd/- H. Coulthard Burrow, Representative, B KITISH COUNCIL IN 'I RAQ 'LB' ■oOo- No.40-8 Confidential. titleInfo.title: 'File 34/6 Training of Women Teachers in Iraq for the Bahrain Government'

physicalDescription.extent: File is arranged in chronological order, from earliest at beginning of the file to most recent at end.

Condition: The file was formerly bound with treasury tags but these have been removed and its pages are now loose.Foliation: The file's foliation sequence commences at the front cover and terminates at the back cover; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and can be found in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. Circled index numbers written using blue/red crayon can be found throughout the file.The file contains the following foliation errors: 1, and 1A.

mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence between British officials regarding a proposal to send Bahraini women to a teacher-training school in Iraq.The correspondence identifies the Queen Aliyah institute in Baghdad as being the best such school in Iraq.
